chapter.title: Overview
chapter.para: Rackspace Cloud Queuing is an API-based message and notification service. A message queueing service is a vital component of big, complex web applications. Cloud Queuing from Rackspace is designed to fill this need. Cloud Queuing is based on the OpenStack Marconi project.

As you develop more complex web applications, you often have multiple servers set up to complete a set of tasks for that application. These tasks can be anything from creating users to deleting blocks of storage. Cloud Queuing is a service that owns the lists of tasks, but not necessarily the order or workflow of the tasks. Many applications handle the workflow at a higher level.
Cloud Queuing creates an open alternative to the producer-consumer and the publish-subscribe (pub-sub) messaging patterns for use in applications that run on OpenStack clouds.

The Cloud Queuing API uses a modular architecture and supports unified pub-sub and job-queuing semantics. You can customize Cloud Queuing to achieve a wide range of performance, durability, availability, and efficiency goals.
Interactions with Cloud Queuing occur programmatically via the Cloud Queuing API as described in this developer guide.

chapter.title: Concepts
chapter.para: To use the Cloud Queuing API effectively, you should understand several key concepts:

section.title: How Cloud Queuing Works
section.para: Here is an overview of the Cloud Queuing workflow:

listitem.para: You create a queue to which producers post messages.
Workers claim messages from the queue, complete the work in that message, and delete the message.
If a worker plans to be offline before its message completes, the worker can retire the claim Time To Live (TTL), putting the message back into the queue for another worker to claim.
Subscribers monitor the claims of these queues to keep track of activity and help troubleshoot if things go wrong.

section.para: For the majority of use cases, Cloud Queuing itself will not be responsible for the ordering of messages. If there is only a single producer, however, Cloud Queueing guarantees that messages are handled in a First In, First Out (FIFO) order.
See the for terms that are key to understanding how Cloud Queuing works.

section.title: Operating Modes
section.para: Cloud Queuing uses the operating modes described in the following sections.

section.title: Producer-Consumer
section.para: Characteristics of the Producer-Consumer mode are:

listitem.para: The worker acts on only one message.
The worker must delete the message when work is done.
TTL restores a message to an unclaimed state if the worker never finishes.
This mode is ideal for dispatching jobs to multiple processors.

section.title: Publish-Subscribe
section.para: Characteristics of the Publish-Subscribe mode are:

listitem.para: All subscribers listen to the messages in the queue.
Subscribers can send a marker/cursor to skip messages already seen.
This mode is ideal for notification of events to multiple listeners at once.

section.title: Use Cases
section.para: Following are some possible use cases for Cloud Queuing:

listitem.para: To distribute tasks among multiple workers (transactional job queues).
To forward events to data collectors (transactional event queues).
To publish events to any number of subscribers (publish-subscribe).
To send commands to one or more agents (point-to-point or publish-subscribe).
To request an action or get information from a Remote Procedure Call (RPC) agent.

chapter.para:
This would normally be a good place to introduce the product and API, but in this example document we'll look at some commonly used constructs. The following an image with a title using the figure element. The oXygen editor provides a
way to insert figures with the necessary markup. I like pie. An example of an .svg figure with a title

When creating an image or diagram, use the correct application and format for the situation. For images with lines and text, you should use the scalable vector graphic format , SVG. SVG and other vector formats store the information as points, lines, and fonts. As a result, they are very crisp when printed and when scaled down or up. For screen shots and photos, vector formats add no real value since they can only store the raster image inside the vector as a binary blob. As a result, you should use the png format scaled to the appropriate size/resolution for your target browsers/screens.
If you are creating an architectural diagram, seqence diagram, flowchart, or something like a drawing with lots of lines and text, then the preferred format is .svg. Typically these are created with tools like Inkscape, Adobe Illustrator, Omnigraffle, or Visio.
If you are working with screen shots or photos, use png and a tool suited for manipulating raster formats.
Note that the for html output formats, the build system converts .svg images to .png at build time since not all browsers are capable of displaying .svg images. The .svg is used directly for pdf output however. To install the server

section.title: The xml:id attribute and linking
section.para:
You must add the xml:id attribute to all books, chapters, sections, appendixs, and prefaces. These ids are used for more than one thing:
The xml:id on the book element must be unique among all other Rackspace documents. This ensures that the Disqus comments are associated with that one document. See Disqus project identifiers for a list of xml:ids currently in use.
The xml:id on each chapter, section, appendix, and preface must be unique within the current book. These ids are used to generate the filename for the html format and also to associate the Disqus thread with that page.

The xml:id attribute is also important for linking within the document. You use the xref element with the linkend attribute to create a hyperlink from one section to another. At build-time, the xref is replaced with a hyperlink and link text appropriate to the format. For example, in html output an xref is just a hyperlink with the title of the target as the link text. In pdf output, which is intended for printing, the link text includes the page number of the target, though in the pdf, the link is also a hot link to the target. In the following example, preface is the value of the xml:id of the target:<xref linkend="preface"/>
Avoid putting the xml:id attribute on the title tag. Instead put it on the element that contains the title. For example avoid doing this:<section><title xml:id="widgets">Understanding widgets</title>...</section> <!-- AVOID This! -->Instead do this:<section xml:id="widgets"><title>Understanding widgets</title>...</section> <!-- Much better! -->
We soon hope to support the olink tag, which will allow you to link to other docs and provide a more convenient way to link within a document.

If you need to link to a url, use the link tag and the xlink:href attribute. For example, the paragraph above contains some hyperlinks:<para>The <tag>xml:id</tag> on the <tag>book</tag> element must be unique among all other Rackspace documents. This ensures that the <link xlink:href="http://disqus.com" >Disqus</link> comments are associated with that one document. See <link xlink:href="https://one.rackspace.com/display/C3/Disqus+project+identifiers" >Disqus project identifiers</link> for a list of <tag>xml:id</tag>s currently in use.</para>

section.title: Lists
section.para:
The DocBook vocabulary supports several kinds of lists. These lists can optionally have titles.
A common pitfall writers fall into is to create several small sections. This is suboptimal because you're giving the full weight of a title in the table of contents to something that may have a single sentence of content. What you probably want in this case is some kind of list.
Types of list in DocBook

chapter.title: Conditional text/profiling
chapter.para:
One important feature of the publishing system is the ability to flag elements with certain attributes and produce different versions of the same document from the same source file. There are two scenarios in which you might use conditional text:
Flagging content as internal, reviewer, or writeronly, for example:<para security="internal">This para will not appear in the customer-facing external verison of the document. It will appear in blue text in the internal version published on docs-internal.rackspace.com. </para>If you instead use security="reviewer" the content will appear only if you set <security>reviewer</security> in your pom.xml file.
Using a feature-flag to control whether content appears:<para condition="foo-feature">This will appear only if the parameter profileCondition contains foo-feature in your pom.xml file.</para>In your pom.xml, you can set <profileCondition>foo-feature</profileCondition>. Note that you can also use a semi-colon delimeted list: <profileCondition>foo-feature;bar-feature</profileCondition> to turn on elements with condition="foo-feature" and condition="bar-feature".

glossdef.para: A worker claims or checks out a message to perform a task. Doing so prevents other workers from attempting to perform the same task.
A message is a task, a notification, or anything else that gets posted to the queue.
A producer is a server that sends messages to the queue.
A subscriber (or observer) watches messages like an RSS feed, but does not claim any messages.
A worker is a server that claims a messages and performs the necessary task.
